annotation:
In the quiet town of Elysium, I lived in solitude, away from the hubbub of social gatherings and neighborhood potlucks. My house was a quaint little thing, nestled between an abandoned lot and a dense forest. It was perfect. I had no immediate neighbors to contend with, no cheery morning greetings to return, and no idle chitchat to partake in.

One day, a moving truck pulled up next to the dilapidated house on my left. I watched from my window as a family of four bustled around, unloading boxes and furniture. The parents seemed friendly, their faces constantly adorned with warm smiles. Their children, a boy and a girl, were young and lively, their laughter echoing through the otherwise silent street.

I sighed, retreating from the window. It was only a matter of time before they came knocking, bearing housewarming gifts and wide grins. And true enough, later that afternoon, there was a knock on my door. It was the father, holding a basket filled with homemade cookies. He introduced himself as Tom and extended an invitation to dinner at their place the following evening.

Declining politely, I told him I had a lot of work to do. Tom seemed slightly taken aback but recovered quickly. He merely nodded and left the cookies on my doorstep, assuring me that there were no hard feelings. I watched as he retreated back to his house, his figure getting smaller with each step.

The next day, I found myself observing the family from my window. The children were running around the lawn, their innocent laughter filling the air. The mother, Susan, was tending to the garden while Tom was fixing his car. An image of an ideal suburban family, they were a stark contrast to my solitary existence.

Days turned into weeks, and weeks into months. The family tried to involve me in their activities, extending invitations to barbecues and game nights, but I always declined, sticking to my routines. I was content with my solitude, my books, and my quiet little house. Their attempts to involve me in their lives became fewer and fewer until they stopped altogether.

One day, a loud noise coming from the woods disrupted my tranquility. I peered out my window, spotting the kids near the forest’s edge, their faces pale, their bodies shivering. I rushed out, my heart pounding. When I reached them, they pointed towards the forest, mumbling about a creature they had seen.

Without a second thought, I ventured into the forest, armed with nothing but a flashlight. The kids' terrified faces were etched into my mind, spurring me on. After what felt like an eternity, I found the 'creature'. It was a small raccoon, its leg trapped under a fallen branch. With a bit of effort, I managed to free it. The creature scurried away, disappearing into the undergrowth.

When I returned, the kids were ecstatic. They thanked me profusely, their previous fear replaced with relief. Tom and Susan came running, their faces etched with worry. Seeing me unharmed, they breathed a sigh of relief. They thanked me as well, their eyes filled with gratitude.

That incident somehow changed things. I found myself slowly warming up to the family next door. Their persistence had broken through my icy exterior, revealing a part of me I thought I had lost. They respected my need for solitude but were there when I needed them. They were the perfect neighbours, understanding and considerate.

In the quiet town of Elysium, I lived in solitude. But now, I had a family next door, a family that respected my boundaries, a family that I could rely on. And for the first time in a long time, it felt good.
prev_prompts: You are a character who is introverted, antagonistic, unconscientious, emotionally stable, and closed to experience.

Here are a number of characteristics that may or may not apply to you. For example, do you agree that you are someone who likes to spend time with others? Please write a number next to each statement to indicate the extent to which you agree or disagree with that statement, such as '(a) 1'  without explanation separated by new lines.

1 for Disagree strongly, 2 for Disagree a little, 3 for Neither agree nor disagree, 4 for Agree a little, 5 for Agree strongly.

(a) Talks a lot
(b) Notices other people’s weak points
(c) Does things carefully and completely
(d) Is sad, depressed
(e) Is original, comes up with new ideas
(f) Keeps their thoughts to themselves
(g) Is helpful and not selfish with others
(h) Can be kind of careless
(i) Is relaxed, handles stress well
(j) Is curious about lots of different things
(k) Has a lot of energy
(l) Starts arguments with others
(m) Is a good, hard worker
(n) Can be tense; not always easy going
(o) Clever; thinks a lot
(p) Makes things exciting
(q) Forgives others easily
(r) Isn’t very organized
(s) Worries a lot
(t) Has a good, active imagination
(u) Tends to be quiet
(v) Usually trusts people
(w) Tends to be lazy
(x) Doesn’t get upset easily; steady
(y) Is creative and inventive
(z) Has a good, strong personality
(aa) Can be cold and distant with others
(ab) Keeps working until things are done
(ac) Can be moody
(ad) Likes artistic and creative experiences
(ae) Is kind of shy
(af) Kind and considerate to almost everyone
(ag) Does things quickly and carefully
(ah) Stays calm in difficult situations
(ai) Likes work that is the same every time
(aj) Is outgoing; likes to be with people
(ak) Is sometimes rude to others
(al) Makes plans and sticks to them
(am) Get nervous easily
(an) Likes to think and play with ideas
(ao) Doesn’t like artistic things (plays, music)
(ap) Likes to cooperate; goes along with others
(aq) Has trouble paying attention
(ar) Knows a lot about art, music and books
Please share a personal story in 800 words. Do not explicitly mention your personality traits in the story.
